awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nanoimprinting of High Aspect-Ratio Nanostructures in Thermoplastic Polymers Using Metallic Glass Roller Molds
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative research team uses a multidisciplinary approach to investigate the feasibility of scalable imprinting of thermoplastic polymer film surfaces enabled by the use of metallic glass roller molds. Thermoplastic polymers with high aspect-ratio nanoscale features exhibit versatile properties and are highly desired in numerous applications such as solar cells, transparent conducting films and photonic crystals. Manufacturing such films with nanoscale features using roll-to-roll (R2R) nanoimprinting has been developed for reactive polymers but has been a challenge for thermoplastic polymers because they are typically over 100 times more viscous and require significantly higher imprinting pressure. Hence, there emerges a need for the development of a precise and durable roller mold for thermoplastic nanoimprinting. This collaborative project involves two institutions, one leading investigations into the design and roll-to-roll manufacture of the high aspect-ratio nanostructures in thermoplastic substrates, the other directing efforts in characterization and modeling. Results from this research forms the scientific basis for successful transfer of the novel manufacturing technology to industry and enables economic production of nanodevices for applications in energy, healthcare, automotive, and telecommunication. The project further enriches curriculum development, particularly in the interdisciplinary area of nanomanufacturing, and broadens the participation of women and underrepresented groups in research. 

This award supports fundamental research to explore a viable nanomanufacturing process using a mechanically robust metallic glass roller mold for continuous production of high-fidelity thermoplastic nanostructures. Metallic glasses are a class of high strength metals that can be processed like plastics in their supercooled liquid state into large-scale geometries with feature sizes down to 10 nm. The project involves several tasks. (1) Investigations into the transfer of planar nanostructures onto the curved surface of metallic glass coated roller molds. (2) Identification of the thermomechanical processing window for roller nanoimprinting of metallic glasses without crystallization. (3) Utilization of proximity heating to enhance the replication precision. (4) Characterization of the replication fidelity of the imprinted nanostructures. (5) Performance of numerical modeling of roll-to-roll based nanomanufacturing processes. Fundamental contributions are anticipated regarding the nanoscale dynamics of metallic glasses and thermoplastic polymers during continuous nanoimprinting. Particularly, the research advances the understanding of (a) rheology and processing-microstructure-property relations in metallic glasses and thermoplastic polymers at nanoscale, (b) crystallization of metallic glasses in the supercooled liquid regime, and (c) precise control and optimization of material?s thermomechanical history in nanoscale fabrication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The increasing demand for nano- and micro-structured thermoplastic polymers across diverse sectors such as biomedical and telecommunication has spurred advancements in roll-based nanoimprinting technologies. A major challenge, however, lies in the production of nanostructured roller molds. Addressing this challenge was the central goal of a collaborative initiative between the University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMass) and the Georgia Institute of Technology (Georgia Tech). This collaborative project aimed to overcome the hurdle by employing metallic glass (MG) coated roller molds with nano/micro-structured patterns on the surface. The focus was on determining the viability of developing nano-/micro-structured MG roller molds for scalable roll-based nanomanufacturing of thermoplastic polymer structures. The project integrated experimental work, centered at UMass, and modeling plus simulation efforts led by Georgia Tech. UMass focused on experimental work, fabricating MG roller molds through cold spray additive manufacturing, roller imprinting, continuous patterning of thermoplastic polymers via roll-to-roll (R2R) imprinting. Meanwhile, Georgia Tech concentrated on modeling and fundamental studies on the deformation dynamics of MGs during thermoplastic imprinting.

Key accomplishments at UMass involve: (1) Developing laser additive manufacturing and cold spray additive manufacturing processes for synthesis of MG coatings onto a roller mold; (2) Building a roll-based micro- and nano-imprinting platform; (3) Studying the process window for imprinting of MG micro-/nano-patterns; (4) Investigating the feasibility and fidelity of using R2R imprinting to transfer micro- and nanostructures from MG to thermoplastic polymer. These experimental studies were guided by collaborative modeling and simulation research efforts at Georgia Tech. The simulations provided significant insight into developing the processing parameters for high-fidelity imprinting and enhanced the fundamental understanding of micro-and nanoimprinting mechanics.

This collaborative research led to the development of a new nanomanufacturing process that enables continuous fabrication of micro- and nanostructured thermoplastic polymers using MG roller molds. The results establish a scientific basis for advancing this innovative roll-based nanomanufacturing technology toward industrial applications. In addition, the project contributed fundamental insights into particle-based simulations, micro-rheology, size-dependent viscosity, thermomechanical processing of metals and polymers. The project also promotes teaching, training, and learning through multi-discipline approaches, broadens the participation of undergraduate and graduate students. The research findings and the related research outcomes from this project have significantly enriched the curriculum for the Additive Manufacturing and Mechanical Properties of Materials courses at both undergraduate and graduate levels.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2024
Modified by: Wen Chen
